content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. The <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein has been reported to increase the growth of certain types of cancer cells. Researchers studying the metabolism and development of stomach cancer cells investigated the potential role of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein in these cells. In the first investigation, the researchers quantified the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in normal stomach cells and in each of four different lines of stomach cancer cells (Figure 1). Using data from a group of <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> patients with stomach cancer, the researchers also analyzed the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein detected in samples of the cancer cells and in normal cells immediately adjacent to the cancer cells (Figure 2). Figure 1. <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein levels in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and stomach cancer cell lines from four different patients (<math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-4</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), shown relative to the level in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 2. The number of patients, from <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> tested, whose stomach cancer cells or normal stomach cells adjacent to the cancer cells express high, low, or no <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein In the second investigation, the researchers grew four groups of stomach cells in petri dishes containing nutrient broth:• <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells• <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a line of stomach cancer cells that the researchers had examined for <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> expression• <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that encodes a small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. When these small <math alttext="R N A's" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bind to the complementary portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is broken down rather than translated.• <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that does NOT encode the complementary small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> After <math alttext="24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>24</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> hours of growth, the researchers measured several indicators of metabolism by an equal number of all four cell groups: glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and the level of cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production in the presence of a compound that blocks the electron transport chain (Figure 3). The values were calculated relative to the values obtained for normal stomach cells. Figure 3. Glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels in stomach cells. <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells; <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, stomach cancer cells; <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mtext> + plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid only; <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid encoding small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) A stomach cell line growing in nutrient broth has a mutation in the gene encoding a particular type of <math alttext="t R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>tRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assuming the mutation is not lethal to the cells, explain why the amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in this cell line is identical to the amount produced by a normal stomach (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cell line but the amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein is less than in the <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. The <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein has been reported to increase the growth of certain types of cancer cells. Researchers studying the metabolism and development of stomach cancer cells investigated the potential role of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein in these cells. In the first investigation, the researchers quantified the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in normal stomach cells and in each of four different lines of stomach cancer cells (Figure 1). Using data from a group of <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> patients with stomach cancer, the researchers also analyzed the relative amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein detected in samples of the cancer cells and in normal cells immediately adjacent to the cancer cells (Figure 2). Figure 1. <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein levels in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and stomach cancer cell lines from four different patients (<math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-4</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), shown relative to the level in normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Figure 2. The number of patients, from <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>100</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> tested, whose stomach cancer cells or normal stomach cells adjacent to the cancer cells express high, low, or no <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein In the second investigation, the researchers grew four groups of stomach cells in petri dishes containing nutrient broth:• <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells• <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a line of stomach cancer cells that the researchers had examined for <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> expression• <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that encodes a small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. When these small <math alttext="R N A's" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bind to the complementary portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is broken down rather than translated.• <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> line of stomach cancer cells to which a plasmid was added that does NOT encode the complementary small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> After <math alttext="24" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>24</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> hours of growth, the researchers measured several indicators of metabolism by an equal number of all four cell groups: glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and the level of cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production in the presence of a compound that blocks the electron transport chain (Figure 3). The values were calculated relative to the values obtained for normal stomach cells. Figure 3. Glucose uptake, lactic acid production, and cytoplasmic <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels in stomach cells. <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, normal stomach cells; <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, stomach cancer cells; <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mtext> + plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid only; <math alttext="S C plus R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells with added plasmid encoding small <math alttext="R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> complementary to a portion of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Error bars represent <math alttext="plus or minus S E sub x bar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mo>±</mo><mtext>SE</mtext></mrow><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) A stomach cell line growing in nutrient broth has a mutation in the gene encoding a particular type of <math alttext="t R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>tRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assuming the mutation is not lethal to the cells, explain why the amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in this cell line is identical to the amount produced by a normal stomach (<math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) cell line but the amount of <math alttext="S I R T 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein is less than in the <math alttext="N S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells.

(b) Identify a dependent variable in the researchers' experiment shown in Figure 3. Justify the analysis of normal stomach cells (<math alttext="N S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NS</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) in the experiments shown in Figure 3. Based on the data in Figures 1 and 3, describe the relationship between <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> expression and glucose uptake. Calculate the percent change in lactic acid production by <math alttext="S C 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells compared with <math alttext="S C plus R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC+RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells.

(c) Researchers analyzing regulation of <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene expression engineer a <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene that is identical to the normal gene except that the normal <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene promoter is replaced by the promoter for a gene encoding a protein typically found only in human nerve cells. The researchers introduce this gene into normal human stomach cells to determine how much <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> AND protein will be expressed from the engineered <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene in the stomach cells. Predict the results of this experiment. The researchers claim that metabolic activity increases in cancerous cells. Provide reasoning based on the data provided to justify the claim. Based on the information provided, predict the cause of a decrease in <math alttext="C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> production by the three groups of cancer cells (<math alttext="S C 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC-1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="S C plus plasmid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>plasmid</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="S C plus R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SC</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) treated with the compound that blocks the electron transport chain compared with the same groups of cells not treated with the compound.

(d) Based on the data provided, explain how testing for <math alttext="S I R T 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>SIRT3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene expression in samples of stomach cells might be used by physicians to predict which individuals have an increased risk of developing stomach cancer. Human stomach cells have plasma membrane receptors for the binding of certain extracellular signaling molecules such as growth factors. Explain why the irreversible binding of chemicals that mimic the growth factors will most likely change the normal cells into cancer cells.

skill.text: 1.C: Explain biological concepts and processes in applied contexts.
